posts.author: KailPendragon
posts.content:
A rework of this build. Two versions are here published, one working on earlier offense maturity and the other on earlier defense. It's a straightforward crit immune dev critter with epic spells and excellent AC complemented by umd, taunt and trap skills. EMA is a great spell to have, but EW can be swapped out for another epic spell of the player's preference given its short duration. Greater Ruin can be a fancy final blow and Hellball a good way to hit a crowd; where epic summons have been improved also Mummy Dust and Dragon Knight might be solid options. Going for other epic spells but EW frees up some skillpoints for perform and the 3rd lvl bard song (4x/day).

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
This build looks solid with excellent defense (AC, epic spells, immunities, saves, UMD) and Taunt for improved AB. Dev crit with a high DC combined with dev crit immunity will make you survive most dev crit duels. The base AB is fair, but you want as high AB as possible to confirm crit threats. Taunt and UMD will assist you with that. The trap skill is just icing on the cake.

What melee weapon do you have in mind? Scimitar?
The AC is so high that I start to wonder if you really need discipline.

posts.author: KailPendragon
posts.content:
I was indeed thinking scimitar but I left the option open.

You are right about Discipline, at least once the AC gets in the high marks. It still can help during leveling, but I'd say we can divert points elsewhere: perform, heal, maxing out taunt and spellcraft, craft trap, some search. Thanks Mick.

posts.author: Maximillian Kane
posts.content:
No worries, I just wanted to make everything explicit. I myself followed the idea of going offensive first and then added the defensive first version as a variant. The best defense is a strong offense (avado will agree with this) so let's get that first... and then let's add a strong defense too
IMO that makes perfect sense in a build like this because the earlier levels is when your enemies will have lower ABs, so they'll hit less in case they surround you and if you can kill them faster, they probably won't surround you for long, whereas the other way around, you'd just take twice as long to kill them and take probably the same amount of damage anyway, just spread over a larger period of time, as they'll have more chances to roll 20s.

There is one exception to this reasoning, which is my Classic Dwarven Defender build posted in the build request section. That build has DR from Dwarven Defender already, which is essentially a defensive property, so taking EDR sooner means the difference between taking a little damage every hit and none whatsoever unless you receive a Critical Hit. In that case I prioritized defense, but any other situation, I'm with ya! They can't hurt you if they're dead!

Take it EZ!
